solution.text:
Perimeter of cylinder = Breadth of paper
\(= 2\pi r = 13\)
Therefore, r = 2.07 cm
Volume of a cylinder \(= \pi r^2h = 215.29 cm^3\)

content.text: Rajiv likes to make 3D shapes from paper. Yesterday, he started with a rectangular piece of paper of length 16 cm and breadth 13 cm. He then rolled the paper into a cylinder so that the cylinder is now 16 cm long. What is the volume (in \(cm^3\)) of the air inside the cylinder so formed?
The dimensions of a cuboid are in the ratio of 6:5:2 (l:b:h). If the total surface area is 1664 \(m^2\). What is the length of the cuboid? (in metres)
What is the Breadth of the cuboid? (in metres)

solution.text:
Let length:breadth:height = 6x:5x:2x
Therefore, Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2(6 \times 5x^2 + 5 \times 2x^2 + 2 \times 6x^2)\)
= \(2(52)x^2\)
= \(104x^2\)
Given that surface area is \1664 m^2\)
Therefore, \(1664 m^2 = 104 x^2\)
\(\Rightarrow x^2 = \frac{1664}{104}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \sqrt{16}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) x = 4 metres

content.text: What is the Height of the cuboid? (in metres)

hint.text: Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2 (lb + bh + lh)\)

solution.text:
Total Curved Surface Area = \(2\pi rh = 132 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 2rh = \frac{132}{\pi} = 42.04 cm^2\)
Once you cut the slice, there are three faces without icing: The curved outer surface and the two rectangular inner surfaces. (Remember that the top and bottom surfaces have icing)
Also, length of Base of Slice = Radius of Cylinder and Height of Slice = Height of Cylinder
Therefore, area of the slice that has no icing
= Curved area of slice + 2 \(\times\) Rectangular surface area of slice
\(= \frac{1}{10}\)(Total Curved Surface Area) + 2 \(\times\) (Base \(\times\) Height of slice)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 132 + 2rh\)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 132 + 42.04\)
= 55.24 \(cm^2\)

content.text: You are given a cylindrical cake with icing on the top and bottom. There is no icing on the curved surface and the curved surface area is \(132 cm^2\). You then cut a straight slice from the cake (as shown below) such that the volume of the slice is exactly \(\frac {1}{10}\) of the volume of the cake. What surface area (in \(cm^2\)) of your slice has no icing?

hint.text: Think about your slice as a separate object. What faces do not have icing?

solution.text:
The volume of the cylindrical pool \(= \pi \times {\frac d2}^2 \times h m^3= \pi \times (\frac{17}2)^2 \times 2 m^3\)
\(= 453730 L\)

content.text: Your school is building a cylindrical swimming pool with a diameter of 17 metres and a depth of 2 metres. How much water (in litres) will they require to completely fill the pool?

hint.text: Volume of a cylindrical container = \(\pi \times r^2 \times h\) and \(1m^3 = 1000L\)

solution.text:
Given the volume of the pipe = V = 5925.18 \(cm^3\)
The volume of a cylindrical pipe = \(\pi{r_ o}^2h - \pi{r_ i}^2h\)
Let the thickness of the pipe be x
\(\Rightarrow V = \pi (10)^2 \times 37 - \pi (10-x)^2 \times 37\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {V}{37\pi}=10^2 - (10-x)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow (10-x)^2 = 100 - \frac{V}{37\pi}
\(\Rightarrow x = 10 - 7\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 3
Therefore, the thickness of the pipe is 3 cm

solution.text:
Area of tin sheet required for 1 box = Surface area of one box
\(= 2 (5 \times 3 + 3 \times 4 + 5 \times 4) = 94 cm^2\)
Therefore, area of tin required for 8 boxes \(= 94 \times 8\)
\(= 752 cm^2\)

Rate of flow into the tank = 8L/minute = 8000\(cm^3\)/minute
Therefore, time taken to fill tank completely \(= \frac {28433280}{8000} \)= 3554.16 minutes

content.text: Water is pouring into a cuboidal tank of length 240 cm, breadth 236 cm and height 502 cm at the rate of 8L/minute. How many minutes will it take to fill the tank completely?

solution.text:
Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims
\(= 2\pi {r_ o}h + 2\pi {r_ i}h + 2(\pi {r_ o}^2 - \pi {r_ i}^2)\)
\(= 2\times\pi \times 26 \times 5 + 2 \pi \times 7 \times 5 + 2(\pi \times 26^2 - \pi \times 7^2)\)
= 4973.76\(cm^2\)
Therefore, cost of painting the pipe \(= 4973.76 \times 0.2\)
= Rs.994.752

content.text: A cylindrical pipe has an outer diameter of 26 cm and an inner diameter of 7 cm. Its length is 5 cm. It needs to be painted on its outer and inner surfaces, as well as the rims. The cost of painting the pipe is Rs. 0.2 per \(cm^2\). What is the total cost, in Rupees, of painting the pipe?

hint.text: Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims

solution.text:
Cross section of river area = Area of 1 + Area of 2 \(= ac \times \frac 12 (d-c) (a+b) = 138 \times 36\times \frac 12 \times 53\times((2 \times 138)-30)\)
\(= 32386392 m^2\)
Rate of flow = 3 km/hr = 3000 m/hr
Volume of water flow = Area of cross section \(\times\) Rate of flow
\(= 32386392 \times (1000) \times 3) = 97159176000 m^3/hr\)
= 97159176000000 L/hr
One week = 7 days =\( 24 \times 7 \)hours = 168 hours
Therefore, volume of water flowing into the sea in one week \(= 168 \times 97159176000000\)
= 16322741568000000 litres

content.text: The Surya river is a small unknown river that flows into the Arabian Sea. The cross-section of the river can be approximated as the shape shown in the diagram below. You measure the dimensions of the river and find that a = 138 m, b = 108 m, c = 36 m and d= 89 m. The river flows at a constant rate of 3 km / hr. What volume of water (in litres) flows into the sea over the course of a week?

solution.text:
Area of school floor \(= 3064(24 \times 8) m^2\)
Area of each tile = \(Base \times height = 24 \times 8 = 192 cm^2\)
Since the tiles can be perfectly broken into smaller parts, the number of tiles required is the area of the floor divided by the area of each tile. Also, remember that \(1m^2 = 10000 cm^2\)
Therefore, Number of tiles = 30640000

solution.text:
Given the area \(= \frac 12 \times Width \times (Sum of parallel sides)\)
\(= \frac 12 \times 21 \times (17 + River Side Length)\)
Therefore River Side Length = \(\frac{808.5}{10.5} - 17\)
\(= 60 m\)

content.text: Hussain bought a plot of agricultural land which is in the shape of a trapezium (see below). The area of the land is \(808.5 m^2\), the side parallel to the road is 17 metres and the width of the field is 21 metres. How long is the side parallel to the river in metres?

solution.text:

Volume of one brick \(= 20 cm \times 10 cm \times 5 cm = 1000 cm^3\)
\(1 m^3 = 1000000 cm^3\)
Therefore, number of bricks required \(= 21 \times \frac{1000000}{1000}\)
\(= 21000\)

=\(\frac{sqrt{3}}{4}\times 2025 cm^2\)
Therefore, volume of water added = Area of base \(\times\) Rise in water Level
=131527.61 \(cm^3\)
Since 1L =\(1000cm^3\)
Volume of water added = 131.53 L

content.text: The water tank in Rekha’s house has a base in the shape of an equilateral triangle with each side measuring 45 cm. It is filled with water till a height of 3 metres. solution.text:
Total surface area of all the cubes \(= 5 \times 6 \times 2.7^2 = 218.7 cm^2\)
Area of each face =\(2.7^2 cm^2\)
Number of faces that face inward = 10 faces
Therefore, outer surface area = 218.7 - 72.9 = 145.8 \(cm^2\)
Cost of paint = Rs 16 per \(cm^2\)
Therefore, total cost of painting the object = \(145.8 \times 16\)
= Rs.2332.8

content.text: Five cubes of edge 2.7 cm each are placed side by side and stuck together as shown. The cost of painting is Rs 16 per \(cm^2\). What is the cost of painting the outer surface of the entire object? (in Rupees)

solution.text:
Curved surface area (CSA) = \(2\pi rh\)
Total surface area = \(2\pi r (r+h) = 2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 3 \times CSA = 1848\)
Therefore, \(2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 6\pi rh\)
\(2\pi r^2 = 4\pi rh
\(\Rightarrow r = 2h\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2}\)
\(CSA = \frac{1848}3 = 2\pi rh = 2\pi r(\frac {r}{2}) = \pi r^2\)
\(\Rightarrow Area of Base = \pi r^2 = \frac{1848}3\)
\(\Rightarrow r^2 = \frac {1848\times 7}{3\times 22}\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 14 cm\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2} = 7 cm\)
Therefore, volume \(= \pi r^2h = 4308.08 cm^3\)

content.text: A solid cylinder has total surface area of 1848 square centimetres. Its curved surface area is one-third of its total surface area. Find the volume of the cylinder in cubic centimetres

Area covered per rotation \(= 791.28 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area painted in 51 rolls \(= 791.28 \times l = 40355.28 cm^2\)

Therefore, the volume will quadruple

Therefore, the volume will quarter

solution.text:
Area of the polygon = Area of square (1) + Area of triangle (2) + Area of square (3)
\(= (a \times b) + (\frac 12 \times e \times d) + (b-d) \times e
\(= 49 + 6.125 + 12.25\)
= \(67.375 cm^2\)

\(=20 \times 10\)

solution.text:
Area of a parallelogram = \(Base \times Height\)
\(= 4 \times 2 cm^2\)
\(= 8\)

content.text: The unit in which the answer will be:
In the quadrilateral below, \(h1=12 cm\), \(h2=24 cm\), \(d=48 cm\)

solution.text:
Area of Quadrilateral = Area of Triangle (1) + Area of Triangle (2)
\(= \frac 12 \times h1 \times d + \frac 12 \times h2 \times d\)
\(= (\frac 12 \times 12 \times 48) + (\frac 12 \times 24 \times 48)\)
=\(864 cm^2\)

content.text: The unit in which the answer will be:
In the polygon below, a=4 cm, b=5 cm, c=5 cm, d=2 cm, e=1.2 cm, f=3 cm, g=4 cm

solution.text:
Area of Polygon = Area of Triangle (1) + Area of Trapezium (2) + Area of Triangle (3) + Area of Triangle (4) + Area of Triangle (5)
\(\frac 12 \times a \times b + \frac 12 (b + e)(c + d) + \frac 12 \times e \times f + \frac 12 \times g \times (d+f) + \frac 12 \times (a+c) \times g\)
\(= \frac 12 \times 4 \times 5 + \frac 12 \times 6.2 \times 7 + \frac 12 \times 1.2 \times 3 + \frac \times 4 \times 3.2 + \frac \times 9 \times 4\)
\(=57.9 cm^2\)

content.text: The unit in which the answer will be:
In the polygon below, a=18 mm, h=12 mm, c=24 mm

solution.text:
Area of Polygon = Area of Trapezium (1) + Area of Trapezium (2)
= Area of Trapezium \(\times 2\)
\(= \frac 12 (a+c)(h) \times 2\)
\(= \frac 12 (18 + 48)(12) \times 2\)
\(= 792 mm^2\)

content.text: The unit in which the answer will be:

solution.text:
Volume of original tube = \(\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h - \pi{r_ i}^2 \times h\)
\(= 25170.24 cm^3\)
Volume of new tube = Volume of original tube
Let the length of the new tube be x
Therefore,\(V_ {new} = \pi{r_ o}^2 \times h - \pi{r_ i}^2 \times h = \pi (\frac l2)^2 \times x - \pi (\frac l2 - 5)^2 \times x
=\( x = \frac {V_ {original}}{\pi (\frac l2)^2-\pi (\frac l2 - m)^2}\)
= 561.61 cm
Therefore, the length of the new tube is 561.61 cm

content.text: A metallic tube, 167 cm long, has a thickness of 4 cm and an outer diameter of 16 cm. It is melted and made into another tube of thickness 5 cm with the same outer diameter. No material is wasted. What is the length of the new tube? (in cm)

solution.text:
Volume of cylinder \(= \pi r^2 \times h = \pi \times 11^2 \times 23 = 8738.62 cm^3\)
Volume of new cuboid = \(lbh\) = Volume of cylinder
Therefore, \(lbh = \pi \times 11^2 \times 23 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow 27 \times 16 \times h = 8738.62 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {\pi \times 11^2 \times 23}{27 \times 16} = 20.23\)
The new cuboid is 20.23 cm tall

content.text: A metal cylinder of height 23 cm and radius 11 cm is melted and reshaped into a cuboid of length 27 cm and breadth 16 cm. No metal was wasted during this process. How tall is the new cuboid? (in cm)

hint.text: If no metal is wasted, both objects will have the same volume.

solution.text:
Volume of pipe=Difference in volumes between outer and inner cylinder
\(= \pi{r_ o}^2 \times h - \pi{r_ i}^2 \times h\)
\(= \pi (23)^2 \times 108 - \pi20^2 \times 108\)
= 43746.48\( cm^3\)
Mass =\( Volume \times Density\)
\(\Rightarrow Mass = 43746.48 cm^3 \times \frac{8.6 g}{cm^3}\)
= 376219.728 g
